ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to evaluate historical sources and synthesize information into presentable arguments.

This course taught me to focus on the subtleties and nuances that comprise biomedicine and healthcare as a whole. We looked at several aspects of public health such as polio vaccination campaigns in India as well as analyzing what exactly leads to distorted narratives or "bad histories" being disseminated to the public. It is my belief that every student came away from the course with a better understanding of how healthcare works in our society and how much work is being done and how much research is being pursued in these fields.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class could be improved by introducing a lecture portion as well. The class was mostly discussion-based, but introducing a 15-minute lecture on the week's topic could greatly aid students' thought processes.

The course brought in readings across virtually all of the social sciences and were even broader geographically. The reading load every week was manageable but it also provided an adequate stimulus for discussion in that week. Since the course only met once a week, one helpful tip could have been to give a short lecture before each discussion to clear up any discrepancies and just provide an even stronger basis for the discussion that would follow. The various discussion posts as well as the major assignments of the course helped refine my comprehension skills and how to understand the context an author is operating in, as well as the nuances that they may be highlighting or potentially hiding.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's a nice way to discuss public health in a region that is not America (which most classes at Yale focus on).

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student as I found it to be the most intellectually fulfilling class I took that semester. It was incredibly effective in highlighting the nuances that complicate healthcare and biomedicine as well as highlighting the number of approaches to improving the state of the two in a highly complex world.
